Change-Id: Id292c777b6c3ed22e06b578de77d517ef295e41c

tagged bvt tests with @ruby, @jvm, @java, @services, @sanity

type in 'rake' or 'rake help' will list available rake commands

Usage: rake [command]
sanity   - run only the most fundamental bvts
ruby     - run ruby-based bvts (rails and sinatra apps)
jvm      - run jvm-based bvts (spring, java_web, lift, grails)
java     - run java-based bvts (spring, java_web)
services - run services-based bvts

Change-Id: I5c54a2adedc24167b5c5384cecadf59374e74458

provides a directory structure where we can add functional tests

Functional tests are where we do whitebox testing against core internals.
For starters, we mirror the directory structure of development. We currently have:
-cloudcontroller
-dea
-health_manager
-router
-stager
-staging
BVTs are essentially blackbox testing where we have a targeted cloud and run
a set of apps with operations against it. Functionals are where we
launch kernel processes directly and manipulate internal classes.

Update BVT to include app that verifies that its URLs are 'open for business'
when Cloud Foundry indicates that the app is running.
(Note: This expectation can be violated for apps running on Tomcat unless
additional steps are taken [i.e.: registering a special listener that looks
for the Tomcat Lifecycle event indiating that the app has started (v6.x), using
a suitable configuration ('bindOnInit' on v7.x)]
- Fix merge conflict
- Fix Rakefile to ensure this app is built.

Service Broker BVT

Set SERVICE_BROKER_URL and SERVICE_BROKER_TOKEN to enable this BVT.  The
test requires only that the service broker be running.  The test starts
a toy key-value store as the service to be brokered, registers it with the
broker, creates and binds an instance of the brokered service to a sample
app, and verifies that everything is working.
